ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: More understanding of morphological theory, different perspectives, etc.
Distributed Morphology. Morphological operations. Syncretism. Head movement. Compounding. Allomorphy versus agreement.

Developed an understanding of the Distributed Morphology theory, and how it can be used to interpret morphological activity of various languages. Gained experience researching a unique morphological phenomenon and using DM to explain it.

An introduction to the framework of distributed morphology: the architecture, techniques, phenomena it could and could not cover, and the theoretical power and weakness (unnaturalness) it reflects compared to other competing frameworks such as nanosyntax.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Lectures were too slow and repetitive. Did not require much critical thinking, so there was a big disconnect between what was expected of us for lectures vs. the final paper we were to produce.

Strengths: Suzana is great, willing to answer questions, makes beautiful slides/handouts, and is responsive to any feedback. Weaknesses: I would perhaps have liked to learn a bit more about why (not just how) some morphemes / feature bundles end up as a single word, while others end up as separate words, given the DM framework.
Course is well structured and covers a lot of content. Pace of course was good. Final assignment was fun to do. Lectures could've been a bit more varied.

The materials are very clearly presented: each theoretical point is accompanied with natural language data examples.

The pace is great for me as a student new to the subfield of morphology (and to the generative grammar framework as well in general): the instructor made abundant effort making sure all students understand the main point.

Strengths: the biggest strength of this course was the instructor! Suzana is very knowledgeable and gives clear explanations of the material. The lecture materials were also super well prepared and thorough, making it easier to follow lecture in class as well as review what we learned. The assignments were interesting and fair and Suzana gave extensive and useful feedback on each one! 

Weaknesses: none!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would, but I would recommend the instructor increases the speed and difficulty of the lectures so that we are more challenged in class. I was not able to stay engaged because the material was too slow to be difficult.
I would! It's an intellectually engaging course that any linguistics major should take.

Yes, definitely. The instructor has tried her best providing support to students (e.g. office hour, paper advice, homework grading and comments). The content is well designed to fit both intro-level and advanced students.
Yes!! I would recommend this specific course to linguistics majors who are interested in morphology, and I would recommend taking a class with this instructor to everyone!
